docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel yesterday upheld the conviction of a Manhattan obstetrician for defrauding insurance companies. The doctor, Niels H. Lauersen, based his appeal primarily on objections that the trial judge owned stock in one of the insurance companies, court papers said. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit found that the trial judge followed proper procedure and that his disqualification was not required. Dr. Lauersen had billed companies for gynecological procedures that were covered by his patients' policies to hide the uncovered fertility procedures he was performing. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fraud Conviction Upheld

docs.abstract: Federal appeals court upholds conviction of Manhattan obstetrician Dr Niels H Lauersen for insurance fraud (S)

byline.original: By Susan Saulny (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: Fatmira Bonjaku's husband is in jail, accused by the police of selling their 3-year-old son to an Italian man in return for the television set that six other children watch in the family's dimly lighted room. The police also say her husband had plans to sell their newest born, whom she is breast feeding. Mrs. Bonjaku, interviewed at her family's two-room shack on the outskirts of this port city, denied that she intended to sell her newborn but admitted trading her son, Orazio, thinking the Italian man ''would provide a good life.''

headline.main: For Albanians, It's Come to This: A Son for a TV

docs.abstract: Child trafficking has established itself in Albania, Europe's most improverished and long most isolated country; government estimates that 6,000 children have been sent abroad for use in begging and prostitution rackets, or in some cases sold to Western couples for adoption; vast majority come from community of 300,000 Albanian-speaking Gypsies, or Roma, who have fared even more poorly than most; Albania's anti-trafficking police estimate that more than 1,000 children are currently in Greece, working mainly as beggars; trafficking is part of larger trade in humans, including East European women shuffled through Albania for prostitution, and is outgrowth of misery and organized crime that has blossomed in clannish society; many families apparently believe their children will gain better lives abroad; Unicef official notes that to most Albanians, sending child abroad is not seen as primitive exploitation but as kind of success; most documented cases of child trafficking involves older children sold or rented by their families to minders, or pimps, who take them to Greece and Italy, where they work as beggars or child prostitutes; photos; map (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, acknowledging that American Catholics pay little heed to their church's ban on contraception, undertook an effort Wednesday to reinforce it, and linked it to the anti-abortion campaign. The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, in session here at its regular fall meeting, also tackled another sexuality issue, approving the text of a brochure that lays out the church's condemnation of same-sex unions.

headline.main: Bishops Open A New Drive Opposing Contraception

docs.abstract: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, acknowledging at Washington, DC, meeting that American Catholics pay little heed to church's contraception ban, opens drive to reinforce ban and link it to anti-abortion campaign; approves plan to write easily understandable booklet explaining church teachings and examining link between contraception and abortion; some bishops are concerned move will strengthen sense among many Catholics that church is out of step with their daily lives and undermine anti-abortion efforts; bishops also approve brochure explaining church's condemnation of same-sex unions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The 19-year-old who was found severely malnourished last month at a home where he was raised by adoptive parents had been hospitalized at age 7, before he was placed in foster care, for signs of malnutrition and for consuming large amounts of alcohol and prescription medication, according to his state child-welfare case file. The teenager, Bruce Jackson, and three adopted brothers were removed from the home in nearby Collingswood when child welfare workers discovered they were on the verge of starvation. The shocking condition of the children -- Bruce weighed just 45 pounds -- has drawn national attention to New Jersey's troubled child welfare system through intensive news media coverage. It has also led to criminal child-abuse charges against the adoptive parents.
docs.abstract: Joanne Principal, biological mother of Bruce Jackson, one of four malnourished adopted sons of Vanessa and Raymond Jackson of Collingswood, NJ, seeks to regain custody of him; child welfare experts say reunion is unlikely because Bruce, at age 19, is legally emanciated and because mistreatment began long before he went to live with Jacksons; Principal denies Jacksons' assertion that Bruce suffered from eating disorder before he came to them; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The 19-year-old who was found severely malnourished last month at a home where he was raised by adoptive parents had been hospitalized at age 7, before he was placed in foster care, for signs of malnutrition and for consuming large amounts of alcohol...

byline.original: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI; Jason George contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As you say in ''For G.O.P., It's a Moment'' (news analysis, front page, Nov. 6), President Bush's support of the federal ban on so-called partial birth abortion was both ''a moment of political triumph for the antiabortion movement'' and part of a larger campaign to dismantle reproductive rights in this country. While the anti-choice movement may be celebrating, many others of us are deeply troubled by this assault on our rights and left with a great sense of injustice.

headline.main: No Letup in the Abortion Debate

docs.abstract: Letter from Wendy R Sheldon of Planned Parenthood asks Pres Bush and others supporting ban on so-called 'partial birth' abortion what happened to right to life of women who might need procedure

docs.lead_paragraph: BLAME Bilbao. Frank Gehry's extravagant design for the Spanish outpost of the Guggenheim Museum was an impressive architectural achievement, but it also started an insidious trend, argues Oren Safdie, author of ''Private Jokes, Public Places,'' a Shavian satire of contemporary architecture that opened last Wednesday at the Theater at the Center for Architecture in Greenwich Village. ''Now every city looking to attract tourists goes shopping for the most famous, most up-to-date architect who gets carte blanche to do whatever he or she wants,'' Mr. Safdie said recently, sitting in a diner in Park Slope, Brooklyn. ''It's the Hollywoodization of architecture.''
docs.abstract: Excerpt from Oren Safdie play Private Jokes, Public Spaces, introduced by Jason Zinoman with comments by playwright; photo (S)
